results.title: Packages from home
results.creator_credit: Dave Piggott, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When Dave Piggott went to fight in the Vietnam War at 19, it was a very different world to life back in Australia. With the help of the friends he made in the army, he soon got used to life there and it’s the funny stories and good friends that remain with him today.

results.title: Reminiscing
results.creator_credit: Alf Thornton, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Alf Thornton fondly recalls his time serving in the Australian Navy during World War II, when letting your mates down was more feared than being killed. When Thornton returned, he spent most of his time trying to regain his lost youth but eventually found an anchor on the H.M.A.S. Castlemaine.

results.title: An Interview with Laurie Price
results.creator_credit: Laurie Price, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Laurie Price is one of the remaining third of those Australians who served in Korea. He provides sharp detail of the work he performed there on the airfields, the distractions and tensions, even between allies. While the war is long over, it continues to affect Price even today.

results.title: Jeff Lindsay in conversation with Sue Turnball: Dark Tales, Serial Archetypes
results.creator_credit: David Meagher, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI

video_links.name: Jeff Lindsay in conversation with Sue Turnball: Dark Tales, Serial Archetypes

results.brief_description:
Jeff Lindsay, author and creator of our favourite serial killer ‘Dexter’, is joined in conversation with Professor Sue Turnbull, as they explore the renaissance of macabre fairytales in popular culture.

Jeff Lindsay and Sue Turnbull touched on many of the themes covered in the ‘Fairytales Re-imagined’ symposium, providing a fascinatingly insightful discussion centred around the development of fairy tale motifs in popular culture.

results.title: Why we luv Jammo
results.creator_credit: Matt Blackwood, Jessica Scott and ACMI
results.brief_description: A diverse cross-section of the “Jammo” community tell us why they’ve chosen this particular slice of heaven to call home. The post-mistress, the erstwhile town photographer, the caravan park operator and a handful of other locals, explain how they came to live in Jamieson (located in north-eastern Victoria) and how the peace, quiet and stunning natural beauty have convinced them there is really no better place to live. The rustling of the wind in the trees, native bird calls and tinkling waterways contribute a natural soundtrack which helps evoke this unique place.

results.title: The Island
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, Jessica Scott and ACMI
results.brief_description: The spirit of volunteerism is alive and well in Jamieson, in north-eastern Victoria, where a small group of retirees have painstakingly transformed an overgrown eyesore into a beautiful recreational park the whole town can enjoy. Once an inaccessible, snake-ridden wilderness, this patch of land between the Goulburn and Jamieson rivers (not a true island) has had a storied history. Although subject to a few set backs after recent flooding, this gang of ex-farmers explain how it was with sheer hard work that they were able to turn around the fortunes of the Island and restore it to the local community.

results.title: Jamieson Primary School
results.creator_credit: David Withers, Jessica Scott and ACMI
results.brief_description: The town of Jamieson, in north-eastern Victoria, is fiercely proud and protective of its historical primary school. With a school population hanging on for dear life, they understand only too well how much a primary school is the beating heart of a small community. It is also a place where life-long friendships are forged, and the school community (past and present) come together here to reflect on the ties that bind them to Jamieson. Principal Genevieve Bolwell also discusses the exciting school programs, which will take the next generation into the future.

results.title: 125th anniversary of Tolmie Sports: Feb 2011
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, Jessica Scott and ACMI
results.brief_description: The Tolmie Sports is a celebration of community and High Country Heritage. A yearly event, it draws people from far and wide to the tiny town of Tolmie in north-eastern Victoria, to revel in events such as the Wood Chop, Equestrian Sports, and the epic and highly elaborate Three Man Race. “Old-Timers” Mick, Don and Sheila reflect on the history of the event, and some of its more colourful days. 2011 marked the 125th anniversary of the sports, and Tolmie Sports Committee Vice President explains some of the planning that goes into an event of its kind.

results.title: Building in Tolmie
results.creator_credit: Matt Blackwood, Jessica Scott and ACMI
results.brief_description: The Valcich’s fell in love with Tolmie, in north-eastern Victoria, the moment they saw it – 12 years on, they are still building their dream home on their block of paradise. Little by little they have assembled a unique and sustainable home using timber and stone from their land and a multitude of reclaimed materials. These gentle souls tell us a little bit about what Tolmie means to them and how they have been able to contribute to the community through the CFA and various social groups over the years.

results.title: Coming together
results.creator_credit: David Withers, Jessica Scott and ACMI
results.brief_description: Tolmie is a small town in north-eastern Victoria with a surprisingly rich and varied social life. A town with no shops, cafes or main drag to speak of, Tolmie boasts over a dozen clubs, groups and community groups, all of whom came together one night tell us what makes Tolmie tick. Centering around the Pub and the community-restored Mechanic’s Hall, everyone from the ‘Secret Bikers Stuff’ group, to the ‘Unfinished Craft Object’ (UFO for short) club, gather to share the secrets of their resourcefulness, irreverent sense of humour and collaborative spirit.

description_for_label: Tolmie is a small town in north-eastern Victoria with a surprisingly rich and varied social life. A town with no shops, cafes or main drag to speak of, Tolmie boasts over a dozen clubs, groups and community groups, all of whom came together one night tell us what makes Tolmie tick. Centering around the Pub and the community-restored Mechanic’s Hall, everyone from the ‘Secret Bikers Stuff’ group, to the ‘Unfinished Craft Object’ (UFO for short) club, gather to share the secrets of their resourcefulness, irreverent sense of humour and collaborative spirit.
